-1000
Pinning dependencies in setup.py is not the right approach.
Pinning should happen in a requirements.txt

You can pin minimum-requirements in setup.py, 
but maximum-requirements only if you know for certain that new packages are not compatible AND you are not going to fix these issues. 
Always avoid exact pinning.

BTW major-version changes do not necessary imply breaking-compatibility, and minor-version  do not necessary imply the opposite. It should in theory, but in practice it doesn't.

Setup.py should just list its dependencies, 
it is not meant to create a reproducible deployment.

Packages listed in setup.py should never be pinned.
They do not serve the same purpose as a requirements.txt.

Pinning requirements in setup.py immediately creates a dependency-hell in larger projects,
which is the reason why am I searching this repo for a reason why this pinning happened.

You only need to pin minimum-versions if you know (not assume or think)  that your application is not going to work with older versions of that dependency, AND you know you are not going to support those older versions (which makes perfect sense)

Similar with pinning maximum-versions.

for example: Is airflow broken when using lxml 4.0>?  

We were assuming it would be broken, 
and therefore starting pinning our stack on older lxml-versions, hence running into dependency-hell.
but after analysis, many of these airflow-maximum-pinnings don't make sense and airflow works fine on newer versions

If airflow would be broken, users should file a bugreport here.

Agreed, for Apache Superset we recently changed our `setup.py` to only set up upper-lower bounds where absolutely needed (when we know that versions of the lib won't work for sure) and leave as much open as possible.

On top of that, we provide an optional `requirements.txt` that can be used as the "reference implementation" used for the builds and tests. Users can decide to use it or not. Ideally `requirements.txt` is generated by `pip-compile` and pins the whole tree.
@r39132  please review my changes you requested and let me know

I wanted to add important notes following a conversation with Tao.

So our security model currently lives in FAB, and trying to reference it in Airflow core (either through the FAB's model) or `AirflowSecurityManager` (build on top of FAB's `SecurityManager`) requires importing / instantiating the Flask app. We absolutely do not want this. 

So there are two possible paths to avoid this dependency:

1. One is to say that access control lives on the web server and anything that needs access control would be done through REST. That means that if we want access control in the CLI (and we do!), we would have to re-write the CLI to go through the REST api. We clearly want to do this at some point anyway.

2. Promote the access control as an Airflow-core concept. This requires refactoring access control logic out of `www_rbac` and into the core of Airflow itself. To do this, could "stub" the security models from FAB into `airflow/models.py`, meaning we can access permission information without loading up the Flask App. **I'm a bit confused as I couldn't find the rbac-related migrations in the repo**. This also means refactoring things that are now in `AirflowSecurityManager` as a construct that does not depend on FAB's `SecurityManager`.

@benjamingregory just did a quick test where I replaced the `Popen` part in the version in the PR with `robjects.r.source(fname)` (from rpy2). It seems to work fine with basic commands and files, so it might be an easy fix.

Yep, I think that's the way forward. This is how dependencies are handled in our Big Data Environment as well. Don't pin unless absolutely necessary, this way we can test with the latest, and maybe package the pinned versions with a tried and tested requirements.txt in the release.

Without the `pip-compile`d `requirements.txt` things can be real flaky though, the builds can start failing as soon as some lib with backward incompatible changes get pushed out.

I think that there can be some challenges around `pip-compile` and py2/3 . In some cases you need both a `requirements.txt` and `requirements3.txt` that differ a little.

@davoscollective hi, i also faced similar issue. i have a `SELECT` query that takes long to complete.

In my operator, i have these 2 lines.
```
cursor.execute("SET statement_timeout = 0") # turn off the statement_timeout
cursor.execute('SELECT a,b,c FROM foo')
```
but the task still fails after 300 seconds.

also already modify the hook to accept `keepalives_idle` still no luck.

As I mentioned in the previous comment, keepalives_idle is not the cause of this issue. The setting you want is statement_timeout its a completely different setting. This thread is not really the right forum for this, it needs a new Jira ticket. I've said that twice now so maybe I should do it.

In the meantime if you want to kludge it up I would try this:
Change your second cursor.execute to "SHOW statement_timeout" to see if the setting actually took effect, perhaps return it from the operator so you can see it in xcom. The cursor should be sharing the same session so using SET to change runtime parameters should be fine across multiple calls to cursor.execute


This SO question mentions it might be a timing thing. One hacky workaround suggested is to add a time.wait in python between the calls. A better solution is to add the option parameter to the psycopg.connect method inside the postgres hook, as I mentioned in the previous comment. Its pretty straight forward for you to copy the hook and operator into plugins and modify them then use them instead of the builtins, if you need that functionality urgently. 


https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32812463/setting-schema-for-all-queries-of-a-connection-in-psycopg2-getting-race-conditi
